title: Welcome
text:
I build things. Sometimes they even work.
Right now, this site is a quiet little space on the internet where I keep track of the things I‚Äôve made, broken, and occasionally fixed again.
If you‚Äôre here, you‚Äôre either curious, lost, or very committed to clicking through random links. Either way: welcome.



Most recently, I built a Recycling Bin-Bot ‚Äî a robot that sorts trash based on its material.
It got me into a competition. I didn‚Äôt win, but the thing did sort metal cans and plastic bottles 90% of the time, so I‚Äôm calling that a personal victory.
Want more about that? Check out the project.





Fixing problems with code (and creating new ones accidentally)
Minimalist design
Systems that do one job well
Bots, automation, and weird tech ideas that might just work





Learning new tools. Unlearning bad habits. Occasionally sleeping.
This site is a work-in-progress ‚Äî like most good things.




Robot thinking, probably



The machinations of my mind are an enigma. ‚Äì still true

title: About
text:
At some point, I built a robot that sorts trash.
It‚Äôs not perfect, but it tried.
The Recycling Bin-Bot uses basic sensors and classification logic to detect the material of an object (plastic, metal, paper, etc.) and sort it into the correct bin. The idea was to make recycling a bit smarter ‚Äî or at least slightly less chaotic.
I entered it into a competition.
Didn‚Äôt win. Still kind of proud.



Basic robotics and sensor integration
How to sort stuff (and my life, marginally)
That failure in a competition isn‚Äôt really failure if you enjoyed the process (‚Ä¶mostly)




Even though the bot wasn‚Äôt flawless, it got people thinking about automation and sustainability. And I got to test my ability to build something practical(ish) from scratch.

Would I do it again?
Probably. But with better wires.


Thanks for visiting. You can find the homepage here.

title: About Me
text:
Welcome to my homepage.
I do things. Sometimes intentionally. Mostly accidentally or on reflex. Like muscle spasms.


The machinations of my mind are an enigma.
‚Äì Also me, probably

If you expected more personality, please refresh. Maybe one will load next time.




üß† I think (when necessary).

üßä My hobbies include buffering.

üéØ I am currently aiming for the middle.

üíº Future goals: TBD

üåê Favorite protocol: https





Me too.
Enjoy the silence.

title: Arknights
text:
I play Arknights. A little too much, maybe ‚Äî but can you blame me?
It‚Äôs a tower defense game with deep strategy, stunning art, and a surprisingly complex storyline involving plagues, politics, and morally gray decisions (just how I like my games and my characters).




The gameplay is actually smart. You have to think ‚Äî like, actually plan ahead.
The characters (Operators) have unique roles, stats, skills, and lore. It‚Äôs not just about power levels ‚Äî it‚Äôs about synergy.
The art and music slap. And the limited-time events are better written than most shows I‚Äôve watched.





Is it gacha? Yes.
Do I have regrets? Nope.
But I keep coming back because Arknights feels like a game that respects your time, even when it steals it.

Image ¬© Hypergryph / Yostar

Back to the homepage or see my projects.

title: Reflection on the Use of GenAI
text:
For this project, I used ChatGPT, a Generative AI (GenAI) tool developed by OpenAI, to help plan, write, and refine the content of my personal Quarto website.
I chose ChatGPT because it‚Äôs capable of giving fast, contextual feedback ‚Äî especially when working with Markdown, HTML, and casual writing tone. I‚Äôve used it like a writing partner and a logic-checker rolled into one.



Instead of staring at a blank page, I used ChatGPT to generate draft content for different parts of the site ‚Äî including:

My homepage, where I wanted a personality-driven introduction
A write-up for my robot project, which I struggled to describe without sounding either too vague or too technical
A page about Arknights, a game I play, where I wanted to strike the right tone between personal and informative

The tool also helped with: - Markdown formatting for tables, images, and links - Writing in a consistent voice - Rewording awkward phrasing while keeping my original intent





Speed: I could quickly test out multiple ways of saying something
Clarity: GenAI helped me phrase things more clearly, especially when summarizing ideas
Tone control: I was able to play with different voices ‚Äî professional, casual, humorous ‚Äî and pick one that matched me
Support without judgment: It didn‚Äôt feel intimidating to experiment or admit I didn‚Äôt know how to start






Sometimes the AI would be too generic or over-explain things I already knew
It required tweaking ‚Äî the first response was rarely the final version
It couldn‚Äôt ‚Äúsee‚Äù my actual layout or files, so I had to mentally translate its suggestions into my working environment
I still had to do the thinking ‚Äî AI helped write, but it didn‚Äôt decide for me





I can see myself using GenAI tools in the future to: - Draft reports, portfolios, and proposals - Brainstorm project ideas or research questions - Get quick feedback or suggestions when I hit a wall
That said, I view GenAI as a starting point, not a final answer. It‚Äôs a tool ‚Äî a very helpful one ‚Äî but the decisions and directions still need to come from me.

Back to the homepage or see my projects.
